text:
*Are top of funnel topics distracting from more bottom of funnel topics?*

I was distracting myself from Sunday scaries by watching TedTalks and it got me thinking about cool content ideas for work (am I the only one who does that? :sweat_smile:) But after writing them down I made this note:
> Would writing on these topics distract from ranking for more relevant terms? Is top of funnel content distracting me from (more important) bottom of funnel content?
I’d love to know what people have to say about this. ToP v BoF. What’s the balance?

elements.text: Are top of funnel topics distracting from more bottom of funnel topics?
I was distracting myself from Sunday scaries by watching TedTalks and it got me thinking about cool content ideas for work (am I the only one who does that?
) But after writing them down I made this note:
Would writing on these topics distract from ranking for more relevant terms? Is top of funnel content distracting me from (more important) bottom of funnel content?
I’d love to know what people have to say about this. ToP v BoF. What’s the balance?

text:
The general rule I think of *for most brands* is that top of funnel should usually start small when they’re first getting into content marketing (at maybe 0-30% of effort) and increase as you finish the core conversion content. But this is more important for complex sale processes (Eg software) and less relevant for low consideration sales where the product sells itself to some extent, and you need more brand exposure.

If you have a clear brand goal for your content other than “sell more stuff”, then this rule goes out the door as well. Eg if goal is all brand awareness or thought leadership then that’s what you have to focus on.
